I have written a tool for VAJ that does this as well if you are interested.

-Jason

    > -----Original Message-----
    > From: Robert Watkins [mailto:robertw@...]
    > Sent: Wednesday, July 18, 2001 8:13 PM
    > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
    > Subject: RE: [junit] Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
    > 
    > 
    > Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
    > > I imagine a tool that parses your classes and generates a 
    > > specific TestCase class with methods to test your public 
    > > methods?  Let's say: you have a method that can throw 
    > > exceptions A, B or C, your generated file will have 3 methods 
    > > (testThrowA, testThrowB, testThrowC...) with (almost) empty 
    > > bodies.  Does it make sense?
    > > 
    > > BTW anyone thinks that it is a good idea? (the tool is IDE 
    > > independant of course).
    > 
    > Well, this isn't IDE independant, but... check out the 
    > JUnit module for
    > NetBeans. It does exactly this, and I routinely use it 
    > over my older code,
    > or code written by other developers here, to see what's 
    > not tested.
    > 
    > Robert.
    > 
    > -- 
    >      "Duct tape is like the Force: it has a light side, a 
    > dark side,
    >                    and it holds the universe together"
